events.target_title: One screen stays black in mutter when using modifiers

note.body:
@daniels Looks like it, one of the displays mentioned is HiDPI. It seems that right now, in any dual monitor setup with at least 1 HiDPI screen everything breaks down. It works fine with a single HiDPI screen (at least for those built-in to laptops) but once an external monitor gets involved (even if the external one isn't HiDPI) we're dead in the water.

This is starting to become a bit pressing though, there's quite a few systems out there with built-in HiDPI screens and they're more and more common at home or in the workplace too. I've had to downgrade to 3.26 to be able to use my system at all, next Ubuntu plans to ship with 3.28 so this will likely start to affect more and more people. Though it appears to be side-steppable by switching to Xorg most distributions ship with the Wayland backends by default.

events.target_title: One screen stays black in mutter when using modifiers

note.body:
What's the way forward here to fix this?

If this surfaces with Xorg 1.20 too it'll basically mean GNOME is completely unusable on any system with two screens or more, of which one is HiDPI. In these modern times, especially with the proliferation of HiDPI screens in laptops, this becomes an easy condition to satisfy, rendering the whole system unusable.

Right now we have an escape hatch by falling back to Xorg by setting `WaylandEnable=false` in `/etc/gdm/custom.conf`. But if this also breaks on an upcoming version of Xorg that workaround disappears. Especially for people on rolling distro's this is likely going to hurt.

note.body:
Related, yes, in the sense that before https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gvfs/merge_requests/12 was merged, you wouldn't even see the workgroup or machine listing. Now, you can see the workgroup and machines, but if you click on the machine to get its list of shares, it will fail if SMB1/NT1 is disabled there. If SMB1/NT1 is enabled, you get the list of shares, and if further connecting to a share, a higher protocol version is used even.

smbclient must be using another trick to get the list of shares from a server that has SMB1/NT1 disabled:

events.target_title: GTK website refresh

note.body:
@davcri Thanks! Currently only the main page is Markdown, as I could not figure out how to mix HTML and Markdown to mark classes for CSS. [This](https://stackoverflow.com/a/23384161) may be the answer, I will try it later.

Concerning which technology to use, I think static site generators are a very good idea, as GitLab Pages will not only make deployment easier, but also will help contributors to test their forks. However, I think we can have more input on which generator to use. Jekyll uses Ruby, which AFAIK is not used in rest of the GNOME stack. Something Python based such as [Pelican](https://blog.getpelican.com/) can be a better choice, since it will be more likely for contributors to know Python when we need something that requires a plug-in to be written. Also, Pelican seems to be supporting rst, AsciiDoc and localization out of the box.

note.body: The main issue with default builder-dark theme and custom Gtk themes is that builder-dark forces a background color for the text editor that only matches Adwaita (dark) theme and doesn't fit into other custom themes. The other elements I changed now use transparency to avoid same conflicts with gtk theme colors

events.target_title: Smoother integration with gnome-builder in dark mode and/or with custom Gtk…

note.body:
As an example, this is how default builder-dark appears with Ant-Dracula theme
![image](/uploads/d8e26fe3c92f0a18c98f1fa6be0cd7a2/image.png)

and this is how it appears with my modified version of builder-dark
![image](/uploads/cce65e0e9da3666d4f402d9c0f595008/image.png)

events.target_title: Smoother integration with gnome-builder in dark mode and/or with custom Gtk…

note.body:
Thanks Christian for your comment. I understand your point but please let me add a couple of things:
1) if you use default Adwaita Gtk theme + builder-dark (original version) + builder in dark mode, you get exactly what you're trying to avoid (if I understand correctly): text area bk matches default bk of other widgets (e.g the tree view on the left)

2) if you force a background color to the text view (as it happens now in builder-dark theme) you have unpredictable results. I mean that your bk color for example could have a different color tone than the rest of the Gtk theme. Look for example at Ant (in my examples above): the entire theme has a cold tone and turns to blue / violet whereas the text area in builder-dark has a warm gray background color that IMHO doesn't look good in contrast to a cold theme.

Perhaps a good compromise could be something like this
```xml
<style name="text" foreground="aluminium3" background="#rgba(0,0,0,.1)"/>
```
In this way we keep gtk theme tone and add a slight contrast with the rest of the window.
What do you think?

Memory leak

note.body:
>  Some users seem to experience _dramatically_ worse memory usage than developers do. I'm not sure how to explain that. I've never seen the shell's memory usage go anywhere near as high as some users have been reporting. Without using the words "I suspect" -- because I don't know anything -- perhaps differing OpenGL implementations are to blame. Most (or all?) developers only care about and test mesa, after all.

I'm one of those users and I'm sure that the culprit are the NVIDIA proprietary drivers. I haven't tested it thoroughly in a while now, but the leak was relatively slow on intel and nouveau drivers. 

On the nvidia proprietary drivers I could easily waste multiple GBs of memory on GNOME Shell just by putting two windows side-by-side and moving the vertical split between them back and forth for a minute or so. Even manually forcing the garbage collector to run would only free a small portion of those GBs. The only way to fix it was to reload the whole gnome-shell. I eventually gave up and moved to KDE Plasma.

I've recently made a quick test with a live version of Antergos and the bug seems to be mostly fixed under noveau. I have to test it with the NVIDIA proprietary as well, but for that I'll have to do a clean install, which I'm not a mood/don't have time for right now.

Segfault on enumeration of GjSFileImporter properties when a searchpath entry contains a symlink

note.body:
Looking a bit closer I guess symlinks pointing to directories wouldn't be picked up as submodules when enumerating. And symlinks directly in the search path might not be followed.

I'll try to dig more this week.

I guess it kinda makes sense that the `GFile` could be considered invalid since we asked the symlink to be followed without asking about the information necessary to follow it..  But yeah, enumerating like this must be quite common so it's at least a very unfortunately effect.

The output actually says:

```
(gjs:9911): GLib-GIO-CRITICAL **: g_file_get_basename: assertion 'G_IS_FILE (file)' failed
```

events.target_title: Segfault on enumeration of GjSFileImporter properties when a searchpath entry contains a symlink

note.body:
In my initial investigation I thought [G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_TYPE](https://developer.gnome.org/gio/stable/GFileInfo.html#G-FILE-ATTRIBUTE-STANDARD-NAME:CAPS) meant "make-the-filename-available", but it's "make-the-**filetype**-available" of course.

EDIT: glib actually complains about this by outputting: `g_file_enumerator_iterate() created without standard::name`

So even though only the type information is requested, the name is also available for non-symlink files.

I'm not sure why I thought that `G_FILE_QUERY_INFO_NONE` (ie. follow symlinks) resulted in the symlink target's name being reported as the filename. That is *not* the case, so the following should be a correct patch: (no need for the symlink target)

```
$ git diff --patch

diff --git a/gjs/importer.cpp b/gjs/importer.cpp
index b4ea3c82..4c42a845 100644
--- a/gjs/importer.cpp
+++ b/gjs/importer.cpp
@@ -706,7 +706,7 @@ importer_enumerate(JSContext        *context,
         /* new_for_commandline_arg handles resource:/// paths */
         GjsAutoUnref<GFile> dir = g_file_new_for_commandline_arg(dirname);
         GjsAutoUnref<GFileEnumerator> direnum =
-            g_file_enumerate_children(dir, G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_TYPE,
+            g_file_enumerate_children(dir, "standard::name,standard::type",
                                       G_FILE_QUERY_INFO_NONE, NULL, NULL);
 
         while (true) {
```

events.target_title: Maximised windows ignore/pass through mouse clicks after launching a fullscreen app, if using multiple displays

note.body:
>  `GDK_GL=always` forces GTK3 to render all windows using OpenGL. That's one of the drawing modes we have (it's unfortunate that it crashes for you; do you have custom GPU settings force-enabled? Like special anti-aliasing modes; you could creating a profile for it in which all settings are set to default values).

I tried playing around with the settings in the NVidia control panel, but I could not get gedit to work using GDK_GL=always.

>  The other one is just normal window DC drawing with cairo, you get that in GTK2 (always; GTK2 has no layered rendering, and i'm not sure it has a trigger to force it to always use OpenGL) and in GTK3 when running with `GDK_WIN32_LAYERED=0` (you can add `GTK_CSD=0` to also force native decorations, see if at least window titlebar is responsive). And the third mode is layered windows, you get that in GTK3 when running with `GDK_WIN32_LAYERED=1`. If the problem is related to rendering, then these should be sufficiently distinct to make a difference somewhere.

I've tried all combinations of 1s and 0s for these flags and it did not make a difference. In fact, I could not even get gedit to display a native titlebar. (though I am certain it picked up these environment variables since I set GDK_GL=always inbetween to verify that it is in fact doing so)
Also, I don't know if this is relevant, but HexChat's window does have WS_EX_LAYERED set. Forcefully removing this flag with another program also does not make a difference. (except losing window transparency as expected)

>  You can run with `GDK_DEBUG=events` and redirect the output into a file. Then compare the events that happen when everything works, and the events that happen when everything doesn't (for these purposes i usually press a specific key repeatedly, to make it easier to find that moment of time in the log later on; event logs are terribly verbose).

Here is a logfile of the following actions:
1. Starting gedit, moving it to the left screen and maximizing it
2. Pressing the 'A' key a bunch of times
3. Starting CS:GO in true fullscreen mode and exiting again
4. Trying to click on the gedit window, but the window behind it being brought to the front
5. Giving gedit focus by clicking on it in the taskbar
6. Pressing the 'B' key a bunch of times
7. Exiting gedit by right clicking on it in the taskbar and pressing "close window", then pressing "close without saving" in the confirmation dialog inside gedit (this works)

[debug.txt](/uploads/b5b41dd50e8086b59f164008c6de72f9/debug.txt)

> What do you mean by fullscreen? Some games have separate "windowed fullscreen" and "fullscreen" modes. Does it make a difference which one is used?

I mean true fullscreen, windowed fullscreen works fine. However, even though I have limited knowledge of win32 programming, I do know that true fullscreen and true fullscreen are not the same thing and I observed some strange behaviors. Let me explain.

CS:GO when started in true fullscreen mode immediately creates this problem. The kind of fullscreen mode CS:GO is using makes it so that when I move my mouse to another monitor, clicking on a window causes the game to minimize. However, when started in windowed fullscreen and switching to true fullscreen, the problem does not happen and it looks like the mode switch is handled differently. Starting up in true fullscreen causes my screen to go black for a few seconds whereas switching from windowed fullscreen to true fullscreen is almost instant. Tabbing out after switching to true fullscreen mode causes the game window to minimize as expected but also does not result in this issue. One thing I noticed is that when you start in true fullscreen, the problem only occurs once when the game starts; once you fix it with one of the workarounds I mentioned earlier, it does not occur again for the time the game is running, no matter how often you tab out.

PUBG when started in true fullscreen mode does *not* create this problem. I can click other windows and the game will not minimize and everything works. However, tabbing out does create the problem again. (it minimizes the game window too like CS:GO) When you fix the problem using one of the workarounds, it happens again every time you tab out, unlike CS:GO.

PresentMon tells me that CS:GO is using a "D3D9" context whereas PUBG uses a "DXGI" context. Both are using "Hardware: Legacy Flip". Minecraft uses OpenGL and does not create this issue; it shows up in PresentMon as using a context of type "Other" and using "Hardware: Legacy Flip" as well. Far Cry 4 uses a DXGI context with Hardware Legacy Flip like PUBG but it does not create this problem. Far Cry 5 creates the problem and behaves identically to PUBG and also shows up in PresentMon the same way.

HexChat and gedit behave completely identically with all games tested.

Phew, that was a lot of information. I hope it makes sense and helps in some way.

> Is GTK window completely unresponsive, or does it have some responsive regions somewhere?

You cannot perform any mouse actions in the entire window, including the title bar. This means clicking does not work (both left and right click go to whatever happens to be behind the window at that location) as does scrolling. HexChat normally highlights links when you hover them, this too is broken.

I can still HexChat type and send IRC messages in HexChat if I give it focus through a click on its taskbar icon and new messages also show up in the UI. Similarly, in gedit I can still type normally when it has focus.

It's as if the windows do not know where the mouse is or have an incorrect mouse position.

note.body:
This is a great change! But I've found some weird things:
1) Without a maximized window on the current workspace, closing the activities overview causes a short panel transparency glitch.

note.body:
I have the same issue.

For debugging, I patched Mutter to log all calls to "meta_monitor_manager_handle_set_crtc_gamma".

When I enable/change color profile for the first monitor, I get:
```
meta_monitor_manager_handle_set_crtc_gamma: serial=2 crtc_id=0
```
When I enable/change color profile for the second one:
```
meta_monitor_manager_handle_set_crtc_gamma: serial=2 crtc_id=0
```
(actually, second monitor is configured as "primary")

But when I disable color profile, crtc_id is correct for that call:
```
meta_monitor_manager_handle_set_crtc_gamma: serial=2 crtc_id=1
```

Also, when color profile is enabled only for the primary monitor, night light works on both of them.

Are there any components other than mutter and gnome-settings-daemon involved in color profile management?

events.target_title: Gnome-shell crashes in mutter when hotplugging MST displays
GNOME Shell becomes extremely slow and consumes tons of CPU

note.body:
We've discussed this on IRC already but I'm just going to mention it again here because I really, really hope to see something get done as there has never once been a gnome-shell version I was actually able to redock this machine on without mutter crashing, slowing down tremendously, etc. So far there's at least three bugs I've hit that have caused causes just through hotplugging (and my experience thus far has taught me there will be many, many more):

https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=730551 (fixed)
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/issues/189 (fixed)
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/issues/237 new

So, it's kind of difficult to even test redocking with the current version of gnome shell. 

That being said: I can help retest this again when my latest MST hotplugging crash gets fixed, but I am really overloaded with work right now. The last time I checked on this, I was told the only real way I could get any sort of useful information was by rebuilding gnome-shell from src with -O0 and trying to reproduce the bug again so I could break into the glib event loop and try to figure out what's going on from there. I barely have the time for this, as I'm going to be overloaded with work for at least one or two weeks more if not longer.

Has there been any update on this? Is there maybe an environment variable I could enable to get glib to dump how much time it's spending in each source? A profiling utility I could use (sysprof doesn't seem to be any help)? Throwing the machine on ssh? Anything that a not-technically advanced user could reasonably run on their machine to provide useful information that does not take an afternoon? And if there isn't, why?

As a foreword: I do really apologize for the frustrated comment here, but I really think there needs to be some discussion on making your core libraries actually report useful debugging information off the bat especially for parts as integral to most glib applications as GSources. Because as you can see, if the person who was experiencing this bug lacked technical knowledge this bug would never actually get fixed. If it could get fixed otherwise, it wouldn't be waiting on me. I really, really think that is a problem.

events.target_title: gdk-pixbuf: fix query-loaders run failed
Option to edit settings in $EDITOR

note.body:
> Various people want GNOME to store their settings in text files

Did you mean to say "store their settings in text files" or do you really mean "edit their settings like text files".

If you really do want to store your dconf user database in plain text ("keyfiles"), you can use a custom dconf profile:

```sh
dconf dump / > "$HOME/.config/dconf/user.txt"
echo 'service-db:keyfile/user' > "$HOME/.config/dconf/profile.txt"
echo "DCONF_PROFILE=$HOME/.config/dconf/profile.txt" >> ~/.pam_environment
```

Your settings database will then be stored in plain text in `$HOME/.config/dconf/user.txt` (after a restart). Only changed (non-default) settings are explicitly stored, but that's the case with `dconf dump` too.

note.body:
Thank you very much for your help.

I've recompiled nautilus using Arch's build system. I've realized that nautilus contains the packages
- nautilus
- libnautilus-extension

On my system the `libnautilus-extension` package was created by an aur package (nautilus-typeahead) and therefore not updated.

Manually installing both components fixed the issue for me.

Allow the ability to set the number of visible items to GtkComboBox

note.body:
Hi, Daniel,
So I was correct saying this functionality is not available currently and there is no trick available to make it work.

It is useful in the sense that the user will be able to see the whole screen (picture) instead of partial view right now.
I will probably be banned again, but I will say it - I believe other OS have the API for that.

I do agree that this will be useful not just for GtkComboBox, but for other controls as well. OTOH, when you design the GUI layout you are sizing the container and not the control itself. In this sense GtkComboBox is kind of unique, since the list is not visible during the initially layout and therefore the container cannot be properly spaced. Hence the request to make it for GtkComboBox.

I also understand that it won't be available in GTK+3, but maybe GTK+4?

Thank you.

events.target_title: text/source view marks for spaces don't honour monospace
text/source view marks for spaces don't honour monospace

note.body:
Well, a small screenshot is in the gtksourceview bug.
Basically, the marks for spaces gtksourceview draws aren't monospace despite textview being set so.
As the upstream pointed out, the location and size of those marks are determined by gtk_text_view_get_iter_location, which - going by the code - points either toward gtk_text_layout_get_iter_location or deeper, towards pango.

events.target_title: text/source view marks for spaces don't honour monospace

note.body:
>  What GtkSourceView does is pretty suboptimal, drawing things on top instead of adding the feature they want at the right layer (pango/text view). I would suggest a proper fix would start with that.

While likely has a point, the other point  is that they're trying to build *on top* of textview, which means they don't want to reimplement things and it doesn't seem textview gives any convenient way to access that layer - not above what any other widget does. Well, short of a few semi-private API functions of GtkTextLayout and GtkTextDisplay.

events.target_title: Unable to explicitly set GtkModelButton role
Unable to explicitly set GtkModelButton role

note.body:
Hi @matthiasc 

From the [documentation](https://developer.gnome.org/gtk3/stable/GtkModelButton.html#GtkButtonRole):
>  enum GtkButtonRole
>
>  The role specifies the **desired** appearance of a GtkModelButton.

and...
> The “role” property

>Specifies whether the button is a plain, check or radio button. When “action-name” is set, the role will be determined from the action and **does not have to be set explicitly**.

Implying it **can** be set explicitly.

If this is not how it is supposed to be used. I'm open to thoughts on how I should be implementing a popover menu model associated with a stateful GAction with desired look (no radios, since button label indicates selection).

Do you have a suggestion for a supported method for what I'd like to achieve? Do I need to drop GtkMenuButton, GtkPopoverMenu etc, and re-implement it with standard widgets and hook them up to a GAction? I'm still new to Gtk+ and would like to understand what is appropriate.

note.body:
Hello, also using arch linux (gnome 3.28 & wayland 1.14) with an i5 integrated intel graphics.

`#0  0x00007f2c35168c09 wl_proxy_marshal (libwayland-client.so.0)
#1  0x00007f2c2d6b58a5 n/a (im-wayland.so)
`
occurs in almost every application. It is usally triggered when screen gets darkened (energy saving mode), or when I power off the screen. When I get back to desktop and try to interact with a window it crashes.

EDIT: I made some more tests:

My setup: computer linked with HDMI to audio-receveir (Onkyo TX-NR808), then HDMI to screen. The bug occurs every time I turn off the screen, then turn it back on, and interacts with windows (crash seem to be when a window lost focus).

Crashes happen with audio receveir ON or in standby mode (hdmi thru).

When computer is linked directly to screen (without the audio receiver), this does not happened.

My guess is that an hdmi event on wayland is causing some sort of context change not handled correctly. I'm quite new to wayland/gnome, so telle me if (and how) I can provide more info on this.

events.target_title: gimp_get_images returns NULL pointer whilst num_images > 0

note.body:
At some point return_vals are sent via a pipe into the plug-in.
Both ```return_vals``` and a temporary variable ```proc_return.params``` with a type ```GPParam*``` are not yet freed.

This function [_gimp_value_array_to_gp_params](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/blob/master/libgimp/gimpgpparams-body.c#L915) creates ```GPParam*``` data.

![image](/uploads/48243d865ab03329b5fd12c93bb16f61/image.png)

But return_vals obtained from the pipe has ```return_vals->values[2]``` equal to 0.
![image](/uploads/56fb67a650d4c78815cf301a7433351b/image.png)

events.target_title: gimp_get_images returns NULL pointer whilst num_images > 0

note.body:
Inside [`gimp_pdb_run_procedure_array`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/blob/master/libgimp/gimpgpparams-body.c#L445), ```proc_return->params[2]->data.d_id_array->data[0]@2``` has image ids. That were encoded at the GIMP side, before passing a msg to the pipe.

At the plugin side. Inside the function [`gimp_gp_param_to_value`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/blob/master/libgimp/gimppdb.c#L322). ```param->type_name``` equals ```"GimpObjectArray"```. But the procedure ```g_type_from_name``` returns ```0```. Due to this reason. An array of images is not being set at the plugin side. The question is why it's happening from time to time?

Next, I tried the following patch:

```diff
diff --git a/Makefile.am b/Makefile.am

--- a/Makefile.am
+++ b/Makefile.am
@@ -114,7 +114,7 @@ CARGO_RELEASE_ARGS=--release

 if CROSS_COMPILING
-CARGO_TARGET_ARGS=--target=$(host)
+CARGO_TARGET_ARGS=--target=x86_64-pc-windows-gnu
 endif
 
 CARGO_VERBOSE = $(cargo_verbose_$(V))
@@ -122,7 +122,7 @@ cargo_verbose_ = $(cargo_verbose_$(AM_DEFAULT_VERBOSITY))
 cargo_verbose_0 =
 cargo_verbose_1 = --verbose
 
-RUST_LIB=@abs_top_builddir@/target/@RUST_TARGET_SUBDIR@/librsvg_internals.a
+RUST_LIB="-L@abs_top_builddir@/target/@RUST_TARGET_SUBDIR@/ -lrsvg_internals"

index c9666757..386982fc 100644
--- a/configure.ac
+++ b/configure.ac
@@ -288,7 +288,7 @@ AM_CONDITIONAL([DEBUG_RELEASE], [test "x$debug_release" = "xyes"])

events.target_title: Cannot cross compile from linux to windows

note.body:
There are 3 problems which should be solved for this issue.

### The format of triplet is different between GCC vs Rust

  * GCC: `x86_64-w64-mingw32`
  * Rust: `x86_64-pc-windows-gnu`

Even if I added new target `x86_64-w64-mingw32` by a JSON file with the `x86_64-pc-windows-gnu` backend, I can't build it successfully because dependent Rust crates (aka "library", "module" or "package" in other languages) for `x86_64-w64-mingw32` aren't exist ([my 2nd comment](#note_94909)).

Firefox solves this issue by converting triplet internally (in configure script):

  * https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/0a2dae2d8cf9f628c55668514c54a23da446d5de/build/moz.configure/rust.configure#160

But this solution isn't still perfect. I met a wrong results of the conversion on some ARM devices (e.g.: I expected armv7-unknown-linux-gnuabihf but it returned avmv5te-unknown-linux-gnuabi on some ARMv7 devices).

I think the most simple & better solution is adding a new configure option like "--rust-target" to specify the triplet for Rust. If the option isn't added, it should be same behavior with the current implementation (use $host).

### The name of built librsvg_internals is different between GNU/Linux vs Windows

  * GNU/Linux: librsvg_internals.a
  * Windows: rsvg_intenalas.lib

So I fixed the path in the patch at [#note_94910](#note_94910).

### mingw-w64 cannot handle Windows's static import library "*.lib" properly

When I replace RUST_LIB with

```diff
-RUST_LIB=@abs_top_builddir@/target/@RUST_TARGET_SUBDIR@/librsvg_internals.a
+RUST_LIB="@abs_top_builddir@/target/@RUST_TARGET_SUBDIR@/rsvg_internals.lib"
```

or 

```diff
-RUST_LIB=@abs_top_builddir@/target/@RUST_TARGET_SUBDIR@/librsvg_internals.a
+RUST_LIB="-static -L@abs_top_builddir@/target/@RUST_TARGET_SUBDIR@ -lrsvg_internals"
```

I got the following error:

```
CARGO_TARGET_DIR=/home/aho/Projects/GNOME/librsvg-2.42.3/target					\
cargo build  --target=x86_64-pc-windows-gnu --release
    Finished release [optimized] target(s) in 0.0 secs
  CCLD     librsvg-2.la
librsvg/.libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-base.o:rsvg-base.c:(.text+0x176): undefined reference to `rsvg_node_get_type'
librsvg/.libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-base.o:rsvg-base.c:(.text+0x1b8): undefined reference to `rsvg_node_get_parent'
librsvg/.libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-base.o:rsvg-base.c:(.text+0x1c8): undefined reference to `rsvg_node_unref'
...
```

It seems that mingw-w64 cannot handle "*.lib" properly.

I'm not sure how to resolve it.
Should we convert "*.lib" to "*.a" ?

* https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11793370/how-can-i-convert-a-vsts-lib-to-a-mingw-a

note.body:
Small correction: Qt supports XI2.

If a window becomes inactive, KWin will attempt to establish a synchronous passive grab on the pointer. We use core grab requests for that; XInput2 is used only for things like touchscreen gestures and modifier shortcuts. Apparently, it seems like there are issues with replaying queued events.

> Since this issue is caused by KWin, we should close it.

Hmm, are you sure about that? I've just checked, kwin replays queued events for evince. It's also worth to point out that Qt uses XI2 for scroll events and we haven't received similar bug reports concerning Qt clients.

tracker-extract killed by seccomp sandbox on i386
login keyring not automatically unlocked on login

note.body:
On closer examination this is was happens.
I have am out-of-the-box Debian (unstable) setup with this in 
`/etc/pam.d/gdm-password`

```
...
auth    optional        pam_gnome_keyring.so
...
session optional        pam_gnome_keyring.so auto_start
...
```

On auth, neither `GNOME_KEYRING_CONTROL` nor `XDG_RUNTIME_DIR` are set
in the environment. Now in pam_sm_authenticate():
```
        ret = unlock_keyring (ph, pwd, password, &need_daemon);
        if (ret != PAM_SUCCESS && need_daemon) {
                /* If we started the daemon, its already unlocked, since we passed the password */
                if (args & ARG_AUTO_START)
                        ret = start_daemon (ph, pwd, true, password);

                /* Otherwise start later in open session, store password */
                else
                        ret = stash_password_for_session (ph, password);
        }
```
unlock_keyring() calls 
get_control_file(). As neither variable is set, get_control_file() returns
GKD_CONTROL_RESULT_NO_DAEMON, hence unlock_keyring() returns early with PAM_SERVICE_ERR, but **need_daemon=0**.
Hence, neither start_daemon() is called nor is the password stored for the PAM session phase
(where XDG_RUNTIME_DIR will have been defined, hence starting the daemon and unlocking the keyring would have succeeded).

I think unlock_keyring() should set **need_daemon=1** when get_control_file() returns GKD_CONTROL_RESULT_NO_DAEMON (as was previously the case when gkr_pam_client_run_operation()
returned the same error).

note.body:
Oh ok.

I looked through the code anyway and I think I might have an approach to consider.

The steam `GenericGame` is started with a `CommandRunner` which simply runs the process. An output of running the process is the PID which we could store on the `CommandRunner` and later kill once it's time for the game to close. I see this class has an unimplemented `stop` method which could be used for this.

events.target_title: Steam is left running after launching Steam games

note.body:
I see what you mean now. There really is no reliable way to tell when the game closes.

The closest thing I can think of is to parse stdout for log messages. For instance, I get this when the game starts:

```
Game update: AppID 457140 "", ProcID 17726, IP 0.0.0.0:0
```

Giving the process id, and then I get this when the game ends:

```
Game removed: AppID 457140 "", ProcID 17726
```

But that's a pretty hacky approach and I could see you not wanting that in your code base.

events.target_title: Steam is left running after launching Steam games

note.body:
Here's another solution I just thought of that is a little better and might actually be workable.

The steam registry is a json file located at `~/.steam/registry.vdf` and contains an entry at `Registry.HKCU.Software.Valve.Steam.RunningAppID` that has the app id that is currently running. The file is written to to update this value when the game begins and when the game ends, it is set to `"0"`.

You could watch the file and when it changes, read the RunningAppID and kill the steam process when the value changes to `"0"`.

I think it will also work in the flatpak because `flatpak-spawn` is just a wrapper around a dbus call to an interface that returns the PID of the spawned process:

https://github.com/flatpak/flatpak/blob/master/data/org.freedesktop.Flatpak.xml#L53

events.target_title: shell-global: Make saving of persistent state asynchronous

note.body:
(GitLab didn't ping me on the commits).  Um.

FWIW, it doesn't sound like a great idea to try and cancel fsync(), or any other operation on the filesystem ($HOME/.local/... state files).  UNIX says you can't.  If your runtime says you can, it's lying and hoping it doesn't matter how many threads you leave running.

Actually I think this is wrong either way.  `g_cancellable_cancel()` doesn't really wait, it's just sending a signal (looks like maybe by writing to a UNIX pipe?).  Therefore you can't assume the async operation is cancelled when it returns.  Therefore you're letting two async threads race each other to modify the same file :-(.  I guess the file will still be replaced atomically, but you might leave the file with the older contents instead of the newer contents.  Right?

Firstly, @carlosg mentioned a couple of other suspects in gnome-shell that write to files.  Are they using the same unsynchronized approach, or do they have a more reasonable approach that could be copied?

---

Secondly, if you want the "correct", principled way to write the notifications file, I think the below does what I want.  If you call write_file() three times in quick succession, it may deliberately skip writing the second update to disk and only write the third update.  At least I think it looks nice and simple in the form of untested python code ^W^W^W pseudo-code :-).

```
# https://docs.python.org/3/library/threading.html

# data_lock protects data and data_thread
data_lock = Lock()
data = None
data_thread = None

def __writer_thread():
     global data  # this function assigns to the global variable "data"

     while True:
         with data_lock:
             if data == None:
                 data_thread = None
                 return
             write_data = data
             data = None

         # Write latest version of data to file
         file_replace_contents("/path/to/file", write_data)

# This function can be called from the main GUI thread.  It will not wait for IO.
def write_file(write_data):
    global data  # this function assigns to the global variable "data"

    with data_lock:
        data = write_data
        if not data_thread:
            t = Thread(target=__writer_thread)
            t.start()
```

To implement the existing C API where you can submit updates for any file, I think you just need one lock to protect all the state.  (And then you don't have to worry about ABBA deadlocks).

```
# lock is used to protect modifications to save_ops,
# AND to protect any modification to a Saver object inside save_ops.
lock = Lock()

save_ops = dict()  # filename -> Saver object

class Saver:
  __slots__ = ('filename', 'data')

  def __init__(self, filename, first_data):
    self.filename = filename
    self.data = first_data

    thread = Thread(self.__save)
    thread.start()
  
  def __save(self):
    while True:
      with lock:
        if self.data == None:
          save_ops.remove(self.filename)
          return
        data = self.data
        self.data = None

      # Write latest version of data to file
      file_replace_contents("/path/to/file", data)
       
  def update(self, data):
    with lock:
      self.data = data

# This function can be called from the main GUI thread.  It will not wait for IO.
def write_file(filename, data):
  with lock:
    if filename in save_ops:
      saver = save_ops[filename]
      saver.update(data)
    else:
      saver = Saver(filename, data)
      save_ops[filename] = saver
```

DualGPU: Mutter 3.28 Crashes on Arch

note.body:
Funny you ask, I just went through finding this documentation right now. I'm rebuilding mutter to get a good trace for #116. Here are my notes:

Find all libraries that I need to recompile with `pacman -Qo <file>`

Adjust `/etc/makepkg.conf` to add:

    # uncomment to build packages with debug symbols
    OPTIONS+=(debug !strip)

Get the package's PKGBUILD

    asp export <pkg>

Build the package

    makepkg --syncdeps --rmdeps

* syncdeps: will install needed deps
* rmdeps: will remove unneeded deps after build

Install

    makepkg --install

Clean

    makepkg --clean

Ref: https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Debug_-_Getting_Traces

note.body:

note.body: To implement short circuit, coalescing operators should be translated into nested if-else blocks. In current CodeNode tree structure, replacing `??` with if-block is performed in child node first, I couldn't find the way put if-block of child node into that of parent node. In my previous patch for null-conditional operator such as `?.` or `?[`- Of course, I found some flaws from it, so it cannot be merged now, but - Vala.NullConditionalExpression contains child expressions in its ArrayList (Vala.Parser makes this done in parsing step), so replacement is done from parent to child in `while` statement. I'm not sure what the best way to implement this is. Do you have any idea?

events.target_title: Scrollable Multiline text editing in GtkCellRendererText

note.body:
Scrolling is only needed in the editable like Daniel mentioned. Now I am trying to work around this issue by trying to use a TextView as the editable by implementing Gtk.CellEditable. Draft PyGObject code as follows.

```
class CustomEditable(Gtk.EventBox, Gtk.CellEditable):

    __gtype_name__ = 'CustomEditable'
    
    editing_canceled = GObject.property(type=bool,
                                        default=False,
                                        flags=GObject.PARAM_READWRITE)
    
    def __init__(self):
        Gtk.EventBox.__init__(self)
        
        self.scrolled = Gtk.ScrolledWindow()
        self.editor = Gtk.TextView()
        self.editor.set_wrap_mode(Gtk.WrapMode.WORD)
        self.editor.set_editable(True)
        self.editor.connect('key-press-event', self.on_key_press_event)
        self.scrolled.add(self.editor)
        self.add(self.scrolled)
        
    def set_text(self, text):
        self.editor.get_buffer().set_text(text)
        
    def get_text(self):
        buffer = self.editor.get_buffer()
        [start, end] = buffer.get_bounds()
        text = buffer.get_text(start,end,False)
        return text
        
    def do_editing_done(self):
        self.remove_widget()
        
    def do_remove_widget(self):
        pass
        
    def do_start_editing(self, event):
        self.editor.grab_focus()
        
    def on_key_press_event(self, widget, event):
        '''Catch pressing Enter keys and Tab.

        Shift, Ctrl or Alt combined with Return or Keypad Enter can be used
        for linebreaking. Pressing Return or Keypad Enter alone will finish
        editing.'''
        
        mask = event.get_state()
        keyname = Gdk.keyval_name(event.get_keyval()[1])
        
        accel_masks = (Gdk.ModifierType.CONTROL_MASK | \
                       Gdk.ModifierType.SHIFT_MASK | \
                       Gdk.ModifierType.MOD1_MASK)
        enter_keynames = ('Return', 'KP_Enter')
        tab_keynames = ('Tab', 'ISO_Left_Tab')

        if ((keyname in enter_keynames) and not (mask & accel_masks)) or (keyname in tab_keynames):
            self.editing_done()
            return True
        else:
            self.editor.set_cursor_visible(True)
            return False
```

events.target_title: Scrollable Multiline text editing in GtkCellRendererText

note.body:
I am posting the current working implementation of this feature here for the benefit of anyone wanting to implement this feature for their use.

```
#!/usr/bin/env python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
#
#  cellrenderercustomtext.py
#
#  Copyright 2014 Manu Varkey <manuvarkey@gmail.com>
#
#  This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
#  it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
#  the Free Software Foundation; either version 2 of the License, or
#  (at your option) any later version.
#
#  This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
#  but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
#  MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
#  GNU General Public License for more details.
#
#  You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
#  along with this program; if not, write to the Free Software
#  Foundation, Inc., 51 Franklin Street, Fifth Floor, Boston,
#  MA 02110-1301, USA.
#
#


import gi
gi.require_version('Gtk', '3.0')
from gi.repository import Gtk, Gdk, GLib, GObject, Pango

class CustomEditable(Gtk.EventBox, Gtk.CellEditable):

    __gtype_name__ = 'CustomEditable'
    
    editing_canceled = GObject.property(type=bool,
                                        default=False,
                                        flags=GObject.PARAM_READWRITE)
    
    def __init__(self):
        Gtk.EventBox.__init__(self)
        
        self.scrolled = Gtk.ScrolledWindow()
        self.editor = Gtk.TextView()
        self.editor.set_wrap_mode(Gtk.WrapMode.WORD)
        self.editor.set_editable(True)
        self.editor.set_accepts_tab(False)
        self.editor.connect('key-press-event', self.on_key_press_event)
        self.connect("button-press-event", self.on_click_event)
        self.scrolled.add(self.editor)
        self.add(self.scrolled)
        
    def set_text(self, text):
        self.editor.get_buffer().set_text(text)
        
    def get_text(self):
        buffer = self.editor.get_buffer()
        [start, end] = buffer.get_bounds()
        text = buffer.get_text(start,end,False)
        return text
        
    def do_editing_done(self):
        self.remove_widget()
        
    def do_remove_widget(self):
        pass
        
    def do_start_editing(self, event):
        self.show_all()
        GLib.timeout_add(50, self.editor.grab_focus)
        
    def copy_clipboard(self):
        clipboard = Gtk.Clipboard.get(Gdk.SELECTION_CLIPBOARD)
        self.editor.get_buffer().copy_clipboard(clipboard)
        
    def paste_clipboard(self):
        clipboard = Gtk.Clipboard.get(Gdk.SELECTION_CLIPBOARD)
        self.editor.get_buffer().paste_clipboard(clipboard, None, True)
        
    def on_key_press_event(self, widget, event):
        '''Catch pressing Enter keys and Tab.

        Shift, Ctrl or Alt combined with Return or Keypad Enter can be used
        for linebreaking. Pressing Return or Keypad Enter alone will finish
        editing.'''
        
        mask = event.get_state()
        keyname = Gdk.keyval_name(event.get_keyval()[1])
        
        accel_masks = (Gdk.ModifierType.CONTROL_MASK | \
                       Gdk.ModifierType.SHIFT_MASK | \
                       Gdk.ModifierType.MOD1_MASK)
        enter_keynames = ('Return', 'KP_Enter')
        cancel_keynames = ('Escape',)
        tab_keynames = ('Tab', 'ISO_Left_Tab')
        
        # Finish editing
        if (keyname in enter_keynames) and not (mask & accel_masks):
            self.props.editing_canceled = False
            self.editing_done()
            return True
        # Cancel editing
        elif keyname in cancel_keynames:
            self.props.editing_canceled = True
            self.editing_done()
            return True
        elif keyname in ('c','C') and (mask & Gdk.ModifierType.CONTROL_MASK):
            self.copy_clipboard()
            return True
        elif keyname in ('v','V') and (mask & Gdk.ModifierType.CONTROL_MASK):
            self.paste_clipboard()
            return True
        # Finish editing on tab
        elif keyname in tab_keynames:
            self.editing_done()
            return False  # Further propogate event
        # Continue editing
        else:
            self.editor.set_cursor_visible(True)
            return False  # Further propogate event
    
    def on_click_event(self, button, event):
        """Prevent button click from being cascaded"""
        return True  # Prevent further propogation of event
        

class CellRendererTextView(Gtk.CellRendererText):
    """Custom cellrenderertext with textview"""
    
    __gtype_name__ = 'CellRendererTextView'
    
    full_text = GObject.property(type=str,
                                 default='',
                                 flags=GObject.PARAM_READWRITE)
    
    def __init__(self):
        Gtk.CellRendererText.__init__(self)

    def do_start_editing(self, event, tree, path, background_area, cell_area, flags):
        
        if not self.get_property('editable'):
            return
        
        text = self.props.full_text
        if text == '':
            text = self.props.text
        
        if text is None:
            text = ''
        
        editable = CustomEditable()
        editable.connect('editing-done', self.editing_done, tree, path)
        editable.set_text(text)
        editable.scrolled.set_policy(Gtk.PolicyType.NEVER,Gtk.PolicyType.EXTERNAL)
        return editable

    def editing_done(self, editable, tree, path):
        if editable.props.editing_canceled == False:
            self.emit('edited', path, editable.get_text())
        tree.grab_focus()
        
        
```

Turn liga off when letterspacing

note.body:
According to Microsoft’s [Developing OpenType Fonts for Standard Scripts](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/typography/script-development/standard), using 'rlig' is a poor choice for any variant of the Latin script. A better solution for correct letterspacing of latf (Latin script, Fraktur variant) is as follows:

1. Use 'ccmp' for ligatures that need to be kept with increased letterspacing (in latf: ch, ck, ſt, ſz [=ß], tz).
2. Use 'liga', 'clig', 'dlig' for ligatures that need to be turned off when letterspacing.

I do not know enough about Arabic typography in order to tell whether the Arabic script equivalent of letterspacing requires certain ligatures to be turned off.

(Thanks to [Issue 22240 - chromium - Do ligature substitution on web content](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=22240#c36) for pointing me to Developing OpenType Fonts for Standard Scripts.)

events.target_title: Night light mode is not working correctly on multiple monitors

note.body:
The fix only worked for me on GNOME 3.28 with mutter 3.28.1-1 which came in to my distribution yesterday.

In other words, when GNOME got updated to 3.28 and mutter was not yet updated in my distribution, for a period of time, it was broken again.

But yes, i can confirm that it's now fixed. 

Should be closed since the bug was with mutter and not gsd.

Take note though that with nvidia-settings 390.48, opening the nvidia-settings GUI while night light is on disables it (despite it still being on). Closing the nvidia-settings GUI does not solve the problem but disabling night light and resuming it thereafter does.

I'm guessing the nvidia-settings daemon resets the color configuration and probably needs to be updated with a fix. Bug reporting to NVIDIA is a pain though.

note.body:
@fmuellner 

> The decision whether the prompt should be shown or not is done by polkit.

Not entirely true ; pkexec ask polkitd, which ask gnome-shell, which use the following to perform authentication:
```
    performAuthentication() {
        this._destroySession();
        this._session = new PolkitAgent.Session({ identity: this._identityToAuth,
                                                  cookie: this._cookie });
        this._sessionCompletedId = this._session.connect('completed', this._onSessionCompleted.bind(this));
        this._sessionRequestId = this._session.connect('request', this._onSessionRequest.bind(this));
        this._sessionShowErrorId = this._session.connect('show-error', this._onSessionShowError.bind(this));
        this._sessionShowInfoId = this._session.connect('show-info', this._onSessionShowInfo.bind(this));
        this._session.initiate();
    }
```

Also, this bug **is** a UI bug.

Here is the result of a `pkexec whoami` (I added a `log('toto: …')` at the start of each `js/ui/components/polkitAgent.js` function):

events.target_title: create custom markers in python
control z-order of objects

note.body:
according to [the docs](https://developer.gnome.org/clutter/stable/ClutterActor.html#clutter-actor-set-z-position), higher values for `z-position` place the object on top of lower values, and you can use positive and negative values, so there is no maximum in either direction.

I guess that, in the method where the object is being dragged, at the point where the method raises the object to the top in z-order, one should only raise it to the top of the objects at the same z-position.

Also, when setting z-position, one should check if its current position in its container children list is still compatible with the new value and correct the order in the container accordingly.

I'm now doubting: this sounds so basilar, that I guess it's programmed in `clutter`, not in `libchamplain`.
